segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. Burke Rambo by Scott Hill on November the 25th of 1988 at his home concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
Is this all right with you?
Yes.
OK. First thing I want to start with is just general information of your date of birth, place of birth,
And your education?
Date of birth, 30 April 1943, San Francisco.
Education, doctorate.
In what area did you?
It's in social studies.
OK. And you're currently employed at Blinn?
Currently employed at Blinn as an adjunct instructor.
Your current military status?
Commissioned officer, not active.
What, uh, why did you join the military services and when?
Could you give us a little background about that?
First time I went in the military was 1963.
It was a reserve program.
From there back to college in ROTC.
Followed commission in May 66.
Later to Vietnam.
Okay.
I was commissioned in May of 66.
You went in the ROTC program at what university?
ROTC unit, Sam Houston State Teachers College.
Was it called Teachers College?
I went there for a year.
Commonly called Bearcat High.
What was your specialty or your job description in the military?
First job description would be 9,300, which was the old designation, the combat intel, commissioned military intelligence.
Before MI was a branch, it was the army security and army intelligence.
It was AS and AI.
And I worked in the intelligence side.
At what point in your career did you receive orders to go to Vietnam?
Received orders to go to Vietnam upon completion of infantry, or school after infantry basic.
What year was that?
In 67.
In 67 and arrived in Vietnam June 67.
Did you request to be that assignment?
We had a choice, a partial choice between Vietnam and Korea.
And if you were going to do anything, you went to Vietnam.
Why did you?
Why did you need to go to Vietnam if you were going to do anything?
What do you mean?
I think if you have a war going, declare it undeclared.
And you want you want a commission, you want to serve.
I think you should go.
It's not a matter of saying I had to go or I was told to go.
I think it's the difference between waiting around for the draft notice and then running down and enlisting five minutes ahead of the postman.
For an officer, if there's a war, then, you know, the experiences where you stay in is going to be what you use later anyway.
At that time, did you have designs on being a career military?
Considered it, and it'd be very...
It was one of the options, enjoy teaching or instruction type.
However, I won't say I didn't enjoy what I did.
You get a lot smarter after you're in a while.
Did that aspirations of possibly being career military influence your decision on career or Vietnam?
I think the biggest thing on that area would be the
Uncle in World War II, he'd been an infantry officer and well-decorated.
Attitude was, if you're not infantry, you're nothing.
It's like being the quarterback of the football team.
It's the desire of nearly everybody that plays football would like to be, gosh, I want to be the quarterback.
Well, be the infantry lieutenant.
The guy that runs the battlefield.
And you arrived in...
June 67.
Arrived, I think, 8 June 67.
Where were you stationed?
Went from, entered in Saigon, entered through Benoit, Tonsenute Air Base, went north to what was called Task Force Oregon.
And at the time, it was a classified project.
They wouldn't tell you anything in country before you left, except to say it was upcountry, meaning north.
Oh, I see.
So did they prepare you in any way for the Vietnam cultural experience?
Or did you just shift over there, kind of cold turkey, knowing what to expect?
I won't say cold turkey, but I'm not sure anybody ever knows what to expect.
And you can see all the news tape you want.
It's like viewing the news tape of a garbage dump.
Until you go to the dump, you don't want to get the smell of the tape.
You know, the analogy today would be you can watch all the war shows you want, but the sensory part that's missing is your nose.
You know, you can sit in the theater and see the big screen and, you know, kick it, but you don't have the smell.
When they burn the barrel, you see a burning barrel, unless you've put your nose over a burning barrel downwind from one, you say, goodness.
You then know what the smell is.
No, I don't think the army and not to default to anything there.
They had a job getting people there.
The, uh, the ability, I guess, to adopt what we probably gambled, you could take an American, he can do anything.
I think we may have overstated it, but, uh,
as far as the normal procedures to see what went on there before you got there.
There wasn't a big push on it.
It was just get in there, you know, you're there, go.
What were your first impressions when you first got there?
Smell.
The door of the plane opens, you know you're not at home.
The heat felt no different than Texas in summertime.
We describe the sound as far as language or anything goes.
Hitting your ears immediately would be a sing-song, musical sounds, a different set of background noises.
Even with city traffic, there's still this, there's a strain, and of course your nose picks up the smell immediately.
Normally here, we don't ride locked inside of buses with cyclone fence over the windows, with armed guards front and rear.
You know, it was kind of like walk down, go buy a customs.
Customs check was a joke.
If you wanted to take anything with you, you know, take it.
If you didn't, don't.
And kind of walked by and said, you got anything to declare?
And that was kind of the end.
It's sort of like crossing the border of Mexico today, unless the dogs.
You mean you had a customs check upon arrival?
Upon arrival, we went through Vietnamese.
Technically, we were guests.

We went through Vietnamese customs, which meant you walked down the ramp of the plane, walked by a customs officer who may have asked one or two people a dumb question, and the other 165 of you shuffled by.
In real life, no check.
What were they expecting you to say?
I'm not sure what they expected, what they were looking for and didn't get an answer.
If you had one, you didn't tell them.
They were looking for anybody carrying private weapons.
In other words, non-standard issue stuff, and they kind of asked the question over and over, does anybody, and of course whoever, if anybody had one, they said no.
So it was saying, you know, just keep walking.
Unload the plane, get the plane empty.
The plane leaves, you file out, get on the buses.
We'll haul you from point A to point B, start processing.
So was it a very big culture shock for you?
Culture shock question, no.
I think being raised in rural areas, seeing rural poverty, and seeing places in Mississippi in the 60s, in the early 60s, late 50s, that aspect's not a culture shock.
Probably said by a lot of people there that we met, that if the Vietnamese would talk to you, they weren't the best citizens in their community, the polite ones.
The good ones seemed to put the parasol between you and them and kept walking.
But as far as a terrible cultural shock, no.
You just saw poverty on a magnified level.
See kids playing in garbage.
see people picking through it, but a great shot to know.
Where were you assigned?
I went to Task Force Oregon, which is at Chu Lai I-Corps, about 55 miles south of Da Nang.
OK. On the East Coast?
Yeah, it was on the ocean, on the ocean side.
Batangan Peninsula, which is south of there.
When you got there, can you describe what you went through, how you were processed?
Overnight plane ride, plenty of bull and chatter on a noisy C-130, which are uninsulated.
Arriving at a replacement point in the night,
told, make yourself comfortable.
The roads are closed.
We'll be down to get, you know, they come down in the morning to pick you up.
First light, you see the mine sweeping team coming down the road, walking ahead of the trucks to pick you up.
And basically, it looks like any processing done in any military anywhere in the world, after they get you in, get the orders out, it was officers one way and enlisted the other way.
Hurry up and wait.
Stand in line.
We'll hurry you over there on a jet, fly you up country on a propeller plane, and stand you in a tin building and let you wait.
What I kind of wanted to get was just a brief idea of what exactly you did, what was your function.
I processed in and was assigned to the
Task Force Oregon, which later became Americal Division, to the Division Intelligence Unit.
And one of the first functions I would take would be to work in the order of battle shop.
This area coordinated, collected agent reports, the paper trail information on the other side, coordinated it
Issued new reports, summaries of the unit strengths, the enemy side.
Worked with our side, the G3.
And trying to develop the intelligence we needed for the commander to go out and shoot the bad guys and do whatever he wanted to.
Provide him a service.
You read thousands of pages of reports.
Sifted the bull, which was most of it.
I guess they saw a good thing coming when they saw us.
If you had some trash to sell, don't steal.
Sell it to the Americans as an agent report.
Tell them there's somebody in the woods.
They'll buy it.
Somebody will buy it from you.
And basically, the job there was for quite a while was building up this database.
The Task Force Oregon crew had been there about 90 days.
The Army had relieved the Marine Corps.
And they were still settling in a division.
And it was process your data.
And some of it was electronic, non-electronic, aerial surveillance, the pictures, the agent reports, sightings from your troops.
And what you're amounted to was a big sifter in a cookie factory.
Can you make sense out of all the stuff coming in?
What do you do with it?
And that would be the normal
That'd be the normal day.
You get up, you go to work, you shuffle mountains of paper.
You try to reduce it down to a two-page, three-page, four-page report, depending on what the bosses wanted.
And that would be the overriding day in, day out.
You also, if you could, got out.
Can you find anything to do outside base camp wire?
And...
Probably one thing to be said when you go to town outside any of the gates in Vietnam, after a while, all the towns look alike.
Street full of beggar kids wearing shirts three times their size.
Actually, the shirt may be the only clothing they had on.
It may not be.
Usually short pants.
Always wanting to wash your Jeep for money, guard your Jeep for money, clean your rifle.
A lot of the children could take your rifle apart faster than the average American soldier.
They could clean them, put them back together, and hand them back to you.
I think the, this part of seeing this many orphans, uh, war created, uh, other problems.
I think that was where a lot of people weren't even looking at your own ghettos.
Your ghettos were, were good.
The, uh,
Life in the camp was, you stayed behind the wire.
We had Vietnamese that worked on the compound.
The area I worked in was a restricted area.
We kept everybody out.
You processed your paper.
You would see the commanding general.
We had a crew, and I worked with him, posting his maps at night.
Learned a lot of strange things in the Army.
When the general comes in, you leave his office, except we made a trade.
We didn't.
They had to be posted.
They wore a game.
They pulled the stickers off the maps.

What you really did in the order of battle area is you sorted out the multitude of units that you were facing and tried to find where were they hiding, where are their headquarters, what are their intentions from captured documents.
The IPW prisoner of war compound provided you the reports.
The national police provided them.
Other agencies, what we had to do was kind of coordinate the flow.
That was the actual two's job.
Our boss was to supply the commander with the needed data.
Then he broke the job down, and you got whatever task came up inside of this.
You may do a project.
You may end up writing a book.
In other words, 30, 40, 50 days on a project.
I may want a two-page paper.
It's 10 o'clock now.
I want it at 1 o'clock.
Go look in your file, what have you got?
Your best guess if you got nothing.
And you do this kind of shuffling.
Were you involved in gathering intelligence?
I worked some in collection, mostly that later, but some in Chulai going out and running low-level agent nets, talking to people, picking up data, mainly going downtown, collecting information.
working somebody else's net they set up.
You simply went in, if you want to look at it, picked up the paper and came back to town.
Most of it was kind of the security side in a way, looking at it.
We worried about how much could they get from looking at what you were doing.
And we provided the other side, our soldiers did, a lot of information that was useful.
You could tell if a big operation was coming because simply just go down.
Everybody asked for the laundry back a couple days early.
Or I won't see you on Thursday.
I won't be here on Thursday.
You count the helicopters.
If a helicopter's going out, it's hauling people.
There's a limit.
You just count them and keep counting, and then you know how many helicopters.
You said you provided the other side with information?
Yeah, all your troops do.
If you go downtown to the village and you talk,
They have their agents in the town.
We had our agents.
Both sides ran agent nets.
Both sides had tax collectors.
The South Vietnamese government would come in and collect money.
During the daytime, the communist government would come in at night, or the shadow government, whatever you want to call it, would come in and tax the people.
We'd come back the next day, fine you with a tax receipt, and take the tax receipt away from you.
It was illegal.
Now you're out your services or you're out your rights, and we took the receipt.
So even if they win, they don't pay you.
You have no record.
You know, drafting in Vietnam was fascinating to watch.
South Vietnamese government surrounds a village, goes in and picks out all the young military-age males and loads them on the truck.
That's how you visit your local recruiter.
He comes to your door.
That, uh...

Mostly, at least during the initial few months, it was working in the office, shuffling papers, visiting outlying camps and fire bases, finding out what they've got going on, going on patrol, whatever the commander wanted, whatever your boss wanted you to do or whatever you could go do, that it was kind of up to you to get out and hustle if you wanted to do something.
And I think part of it was wanting to get away from the flagpole, get away from headquarters.
I'm here, send me to the woods.
I'm here, let me go to the woods.
There was a joke used to tell in Vietnam, if you messed up in the base camp, they sent you to the woods.
If you messed up in the woods, they sent you to the base camp.
And depending on where you were standing and what you wanted to do, mess up.
You get a change of scenery.
You foul up here, we ship you out.
You foul up out there, they ship you back.
So when you couldn't stand what you were doing, you asked for a transfer.
How did the military train you for the function?
Was it in the States?
Yeah, when I left Fort Benning, went to Fort Holabird in Baltimore, Maryland, received the initial intelligence training.
And the Army cut short the training program
and had a levy need, which is a requirement for 400 officers in Vietnam, 400 intelligence officers.
So you go through the school, a very quick one.
You come out the other side wearing the brass that says you are now an intelligence lieutenant.
Even if you can't spell it, you are one.
Steal the Marine line.
And on to Vietnam.
give you 30 days leave, and send you over.
Did you feel like you were adequately prepared?
Oh, I don't think any lieutenant would ever have all the training you want.
I think you always want more, but so what?
You got about the same amount the other guy got.
The infantry officer going to Vietnam is from ROTC.
Got nine weeks at Fort Benning.
I did the nine weeks at Benning, then went on to Fort Hollabird, did their training cycle, and shipped to Vietnam.
So you were in training longer than the infantry lieutenant who got there.
In other words, we had people who left nine weeks after arriving in mid-January straight to Vietnam.
We went to another school, and we caught up with them in June.
They're already there.
They've been there a couple of months.
What happened to you guys?
We went to intelligence school.
They had a requirement at that era that all intelligence officers had to be trained in one of the combat arms, infantry, artillery, or armor.
And due to my uncle's persuasiveness, I chose infantry.
That may not be all it was put up to be,
You know, it's like wanting a quarterback in the Super Bowl.
Every kid did to play football.
So you were there right before Ted, around Ted.
Did you notice an increase in information or intelligence?
Did you have any inkling through the intelligence that you gathered that something like that was about to happen?
We had reports.
But the problem with reports is you always have reports one side saying it's going to happen.
Pick a date, any date you want in Vietnam, and you could have an attack on it.
And you had a report that said it's going to happen.
It's how true is the source.
There were clues.
And we had captured, which we learned later, prior to Tet, the Tet documents for I-Corps.
United States Marine Patrol went out, picked him up, came back, and did not process their documents.
That always looking back, it's easy to pick out, yeah, here's the report.
I absolutely knew this guy was right.
Looking at it at the moment, you always expect
You can be shelled anytime, whether it's going to be well-organized, high level, and happen like it turned out to be is another guess.
Probably the answer is, in the place I worked, sure, there was a guess that everybody wanted to bet on one side, put your money on, Ted's going to be exciting.
The optimist said, quit worrying.
The pessimist won the argument in this case.
But we didn't have...
Copies, and by the way, their copies that they wrote never did exactly name your place.
They always used code names for their targets.
So even if you had one, you knew it was going to happen sometime because they wrote these orders.
It's how you interpret it.
Looking backwards, yeah, we saw a lot of things.
We didn't read the signals.
Did you find that a lot of the intelligence that you gathered and passed on was not active on?
Oh.
First off, you get it that you pass it and the boss does what he wants with it.
You may never know first if it's acted on or not.

You hand your report out, they send it down to the field, somebody in the field does something, you don't know if they moved on that report, another report, a guy steps in a hole and breaks his leg and finds a tunnel.
It's how do you find it.
Most intelligence reports
if you want to consider them one sheet of paper, are never acted on.
In other words, you may spend six months piecing together a picture that's fuzzy, then go sell the commander, let's act on it.
And you go out there and then nothing happens.
And you know what the commander says after that?
Don't bother me.
What are you guys doing back here?
You know, what's going on behind the building with the shut doors and the shame drawn?
Not work, I know.
We went out and looked and didn't find anything.
And you may have 8, 10, 12, 20 dry runs for every time you hit something.

The problem was that if the troops in the field, and by the way, the troops in the field at least traditionally and a good bit of experience in Vietnam suggest, see things, they had to be taught to turn it in.
Teaching troops to turn it in is never simple.
Teaching a guy not to take the enemy soldier's wallet is never simple.
Not only when he gets the wallet with the money in it or the picture in it and says, I got one off a dead guy, he also destroyed any intelligence information if he keeps the paper.
Throws the papers away, we can never find which body they came from.
You know, we created problems.
But you always hoped your intelligence is better.
You'd love to fall into the road map, get the whole plan of the entire war laid out for you and have the document.
Normally what you get...
It's like looking through a telescope without having a map.
You've got hundreds of pictures of whatever you're looking at.
What is it?
And to make fun of intelligence might be to talk about from the old, the six men of Endistan.
They were all blind.
They went out to see what an elephant looked like.
One walks under it, there's nothing there.
It's like the air.
One grabbed his tail.
It's like a rope.
One grabbed his trunk.
One grabbed his leg.

describe what you grabbed each one of them described an elephant they were all right as far as it went and that's the thing with intelligence it first has to be timely it has to be accurate and if you're going to make a living out of this and stay there you've got to be believable to the boss and that's the hard part what are you guys selling today we went you know last month last year last time out we found nothing now what makes this report better than the other one
And it's not like going out and selling cars.
In fact, a lot of times in Vietnam, we couldn't tell them all we found.
We could give you a hint.
Do this, do something.
In fact, we had a problem policy that changed before it was over was we had several times we knew attacks would occur and we didn't tell units.
Why was that?
The source of the information
was worth more than the unit.
What's the sense of having the information?
If you have a source and the other side figures out the only source you have, it's a unique, critical side.
If they know where the leak is, they can plug it any time they want.
Instead of tipping it off for five men,
I want to save it for something worthwhile because they'll know how we did it eventually.
You know, it's like playing poker.
You may throw in a few cards and fold.
You may want to play the whole hand.
If you play the whole hand and there was only one way they could have said this and they discover they've got a security problem, they'll fix it.
So you better play it when it's important.
You just don't play it for them just to do it.
You did that all the way till June of 68?
I worked in the order of battle six, seven months and crossed out with the IPW, the interrogation section.
Eventually I ended up in the interrogation section.
doing interrogations and processing captured documents, between doing whatever, the patrolling, the women on long range, the visitation to the SF camps, the out of compound work.
Went back in the compound division where I either performed documents or interrogations.
So you went into the field?
You went to the field, but you didn't stay.
Other words, I would be sent out with a sergeant, with two sergeants, with whatever the boss, however many interrogation teams you need.
Get a team out, you do your job, you're assigned to some task force, you're attached.
As soon as the operation's over, you come home, the unit goes back to their base camp.
Next time out, whoever's on rotation goes out, or as required.
Look, what exactly can you describe exactly like a typical operation?
Typical operation probably would go out and join the infantry.
And if someone jokingly said about it, walk through miles and miles and nowhere, fly you out, dump you off, and walk.
And most of the time, you did not get prisoners.
If you got them, they were wounded.
If they were wounded, they were put on a helicopter and flown to the rear if they were severely wounded.
If you got one in the field that wasn't wounded severely, you had the problem of however you want to sort out, is he lying and telling the truth?
If I'm holding a gun upside your head or whoever's holding it, bringing you into me when they turn you over to me.
If I ask you a question, if you ask it the wrong way, you're going to always answer the question, trying to figure out what the guy wants to hear.
Unless you want to die right there.
And then you go out and you try to check the story the guy's giving you, and there's nothing to it.
So then you ship him on back as a prisoner.
Actually, what we had, what we held them was the Vietnamese government ran the only prison camps.
We ran detention collection points.
We would hold them, process them, decide were they innocent civilians.
If so, turn them loose.
If not, then we forward them to the next level, the Vietnamese government.
which ran their prisoner of war camps.
The field interrogations were usually at a low level, no great sophistication.
Where'd you come from?
Where you going?
What's your unit doing?
How many of them?
What are you doing out here?
You know, you get dumb answers, and this is where you may find cultures different.
It may pay you to sit and ask them, how's your grandfather?
Have you had a letter from home lately?
No.
We approach it one direction.
The Vietnamese approach the answering the questions the other way.
And if you had the time and wanted one of them to tell you what he was doing, you gave him a notebook if he could read and write.
And you told him to write out everything he'd ever done in the Army, self-critique.
And the little guy sits down and starts writing and writes you mountains of it.
Describe all the stuff you've ever done since the day you joined the Army.
And he starts.
Oh, you won't.
It's the last page.
What was he doing?
just before the two of y'all's armies bumped into each other.
I don't want to know who his cook was, but I'm saying we want to know what's he doing, but to get him there, you may have to let him do all his talking and go the other way.
Because of the cultural difference?
Their way of doing business, the communist system, that and culture.
You tried to take advantage of early on interrogations.
You tried to find out religions.
whatever, take advantage of it.
Take advantage of the lack of it.
If what you had to do was find something that made the other guy uncomfortable, can I get there?
Can I get him to talk?
By the way, the ultimate loss is if you beat him until he talks.
You go anywhere you want to with that report, but 9 out of 10, although the odds may be even higher, it won't be true because I'm going to tell you anything to get you to stop.
So what you wanted was you wanted him to quote unquote willingly tell you.
The only problem you had was, Lieutenant, we want the report on our desk in an hour.
So that gives you 30 minutes to shake on him, 30 minutes to write the report, and just hope he had something to say.
No, sir, he didn't know a thing.
All he did was carry rice.
All he did was dig ditches for them.
The thousand and one things that both armies do, you caught people from stupid to brilliant.
And it's sort of like saying, what do you expect the average Vietnamese soldier who infiltrated from up north, who had walked down south, it may have taken him two months to get there,
He's been there a couple months, hiding in the woods, coming closer and closer to your camp.
Your unit goes out, surprise him, and you catch him, and you ask him where he is, and he has no idea because he can't read a map.
He was just sent to do a job.
And they can usually name the officer above them, the unit they're in.
They have a lot of nicknames, code names for their units.
He had a thing called a letterbox number, which would be like our zip code.
So he could have a letter written to him.
But a lot of times they didn't know a lot of things.
But it's these small pieces, five words here, ten words there, a sentence or two here.
Once in a while you hit, it's like digging for diamonds.
Once in a while you find one, most of the time you're in the hog pen when you're through digging.
There's not a hit.
So you had, did you know any Vietnamese, or did you have a South Vietnamese?
We used interpreters to start with.
We found a lot of, some of the prisoners you encountered spoke English, some spoke French.
Gradually you could learn, or you did learn to do it orally as far as reading and writing.
It took more time.
Worked on some, did not go to a school.
It was haphazard.
You learned the military terminology you needed, but you couldn't order dinner in a good restaurant.
So, typical field operation would just go up trying to flush the quail.
Yeah, you went on walks in the, and made fun of it, walks in the woods, shake down rice paddies.
There's a report, which you may or may not have furnished them, but there's something going on in the area.
The commander says, check it out.
You may send 150 guys.
You may send 500.
You may send 1,000, the battalion, depending on what's going on.
And usually, you tagged along with the lead element of the company right behind it, or whatever it was near the front.
So if something happened, they had one of you worthless intel types up there.
And I'm over and over, what do you guys do?
Well, we talk to prisoners, but you've got to catch them first.
You bring me one.
You bring the guy in, and no documents on him.
His wallet's missing.
He swears it was stolen.
No papers.
You simply hurt yourselves and what you had to do.
A lot of the time we spent nearly as much time in the field educating the troops, trying to talk to them.

But, you know, if you think of the problem you're facing, here it is, you and the other guy have just shot each other, your friends have been shot, you remind them of all the things that's happened in the past, and now I want you to turn loose to this one guy everybody's getting ready to beat up on and give him to me.
Are you kidding?
We're not through.
It's like a football game.
No, no, not until after we pile on.
If you kill him, you kill your friends.
It's the best way to describe it to anybody.
Every time you killed one without getting anything from him, you just didn't bring him in.
And by the way, there's not a big neon sign on the battlefield that says take prisoners.
There's a requirement if you do get them that you treat them right.
However, the difference between being a dead, attempted surrender
And a prisoner is, you run through a hedgerow carrying a stick.
It looks like a rifle.
We shoot and kill you.
But once the fighting's over, we've got you.
We're not supposed to kill you.
It was convincing guys that their units had been mauled on.
Some of their buddies had been killed, not cleanly either.
Give me a prisoner.
You caught the guy.
Here's the report you wrote in the field, or you just brought him to me.
You've tagged him.
Here's where we caught him.
We caught him with a rifle.
What are you guys going to do?
We're going to talk to them.
Talk.
I want more than talk.
That's what we're trying to do, fellas, is get some answers to where they are, what they're doing, so we can get more of them.
When you don't bring them to us, we can't do anything.
You're along then as an observer.
What you can see and make your best guess, add up all the strange facts in the field, you've got that.
Other than that, you're out.
You're no better than the next guy.
We try to be more organized about it.
That's what the whole business of the branch was.
Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.
There were commanders in Vietnam who didn't care about intelligence.
They didn't believe in it.
First, you got 99 bad reports.
Can't you fools sort out which one of these is true?
Yes and no.
We believe.
It's sort of like playing poker at the table, and you ask me, what are the other five poker players holding in their hand?
If I've seen all the discards, they were face up, they drew their card face up, I have a clue on how they're betting if I'm a good player.
But if you played all seven cards down, and you ask what are they holding, I can only look at the three they've played, the four they've played, the five, and make a guess.
Other words, what we tried to do was guess what their commander was going to do.
Do you think that the hostilities that the soldiers felt towards these prisoners was typical of Vietnam, or typical of any war, or just unique of the Vietnam situation?
Oh, I think that any time any two armies are out there killing each other, that
You have a problem because the first problem is you're supposed to hate the other side's government, not the other side's soldier necessarily.
He's a professional, too.
The problem was keeping that attitude in mind doesn't do a lot to motivate you to take the hill.
It's like the old first sergeant said, if you kill enough of them, he'll come along and take the names.
If he's too busy, never mind, we'll just skip name-taking.
You know, we got a job.
Well, it's how you keep, and the strange thing is, it's how you keep your emotions under control.
You're doing a job out there.
The moment you forget what your job is, and by the way, any lieutenant's job wasn't to fire a weapon.
The job's traffic cop.
You direct people.
When you had to start shooting, you lost control because you're now playing the part of a rifleman, a private.
Somebody's got to run the unit or nobody, and it may be nobody sometimes.
And that's one of the problems we had.
I think it takes a few battles.
It's just like playing football, but where do you practice war scrimmages?
We have training exercises.
These are supposed to simulate war.
Nothing, no training table can ever simulate war because if you go to Benning or any of the places and you make a mistake, the land grader stops and says, Lieutenant, that's not the school solution.
That's good as far as it goes.
However, on the battlefield, there's not going to be any land grader or any referee or any zebra
to replay the hands you're dealt.
It's when the two of you units or armies bump into each other, both of you play what you hold.
The guy that plays it best wins.
There are stupid, dumb things the American army walked into in Vietnam.
There were stupid traps we set up that any American would have seen it, but they weren't Americans.
They came walking down the trail and walked right into your hands.
You think of this.
You go out and dig foxholes and lay in the woods and set an ambush.
You stay quiet and let the other unit walk up 20 yards from you, 25 yards, and then holler surprise, whatever you want to holler.
Battles do strange things to people.
Some of them don't fire their rifles.
Probably in Vietnam, one in five, one in six, and a lot of them didn't shoot.
The other problem is you get some guys you can't stop.
You put a leash on them, it's an Exxon Tiger in your tank thing.
Your job as a lieutenant is direct traffic.
If you're an infantry lieutenant, you have four squad leaders and a platoon sergeant, five people you're responsible for.
Everybody's responsible for four or five others.
Everybody's got to make sure the job's done.
When you have problems, it's when you go out there and nobody does that job, the chain of command breaks down.
Then you get into the, we've got a problem, sir.
And what do we do about it?
Well, that's when it becomes...
Gosh, I wasn't there either type answer.
Nobody was there.
If it goes wrong, try to find anyone who wants to stand up and say, yeah, yeah, we did that.
If it went right, everybody wants to be dead center in the picture saying, see what I did, Mom.
Nobody would take responsibility.
Nobody wants to blame.
Everybody wants the credit.
If it was a million dollars, it would be giving away everybody's kin to you.
And if you owe a bill, try to catch one.
So I just think you're, how successful do you feel like, or is there any measure of success for you?
Yeah, there's measures of success.
I think if you go out and you see that you've converted even a few of these guys, the riflemen, to collect the data, to leave the documents on the body until you can get there.
To show you the stuff, you know, we had training programs.
We'd go out and say, if you see any of these things, the old Army show-and-tell program, show them a picture of all this trash the enemy has, all their stuff.
If you see any of it, don't touch it, don't move it, come get us.
We've got the people that need to look at it exactly as it is.
Don't tear it up.
Don't bring it to us because you've destroyed a lot of it.
Yeah, there were successes.
There were also failures.
It was just like any program.
It was always ongoing.
The thing I think that made Vietnam tough, every 12 months, everybody in the unit left and went home.
What we had in Vietnam, probably the nice about it, was 21-year lesson plans, which always learned the same thing no matter which year you learned them in.
And reading the files afterwards tended to suggest that we always learned the same thing, how to tie your shoes.
You didn't learn what you needed.
You were always learning basics, never mind getting on to the advanced things.
Oh, the chance they were new.
Some of them were old guys, some of them were new guys, and there was no old guy, new guy loyalty.
It was your old friends, basically.
And unit cohesiveness, and I think the thing, looking back, that the Army's even learned is you don't send people as individual replacements to wars.
You send units.
We've gone back to what the British had, the old British Army Regiment.
The American Army's called it the cohort.
We've gone back to this group that's going to go to school together, train together, fight together, and be replaced together.
It's not we're going to shuffle you out on a pass
Graduation came 365 days a year in Vietnam.
Your year's up, pack it.
And you went out one time with four people who'd been there a year.
You were the rookie.
Next time you went in the woods, you'd been there six months.
You had one old man with you and two rookies.
The last time you go out, you're the old man.
They're the rookies.
There was never any of this.
We worked together, trained together,
